185982309.review:
There's a nice game here.. somewhere. It's just hard / tedious to get into. A bit too tedius really.

Important note: This review is written shortly before 4.0, so may warrant an update soon.

The UI can be unintuitive at times. (How long it took me to figure out how to merge fleets is just embarrassing)

Information about what some start actually does and what influences it can be hard ot come by. (What feeds into colony stability? any deficit? crime? defence armies? assult armies?. How to i get a good overview of all my trade routes, not just 1 station related stuff? Pirate spawns, what can you do to prevent them that actually works?  stations? do I need one in every system for it to work? or in trade-protection range? does any random ship work for deterrence? will they just spawn randomly?)

Managing land armies is a pain in the ass. It all boils down to comparing numbers anyway, but it takes so much fiddly busiwork that adds little.

Wargoals and peace are ... poorly done frankly. You can steamroll some city state controll all of their territory. but still be forced to settle for white peace (reset territory to pre war state and gain nothing) because you didn't invade 1 planet. If a stray colony revolts and breaks off they are immortal for 10 years. Maybe an experienced player would be used to playing aorund this, but for a new player it's just a "WTF wasted like 30 minutes for nothing, and now have to wait out a timer before i can try again?"

Tried a federation game. Basically pointless, it takes away most of what little control you still had and gives little in return. (or maybe its worthwhile, but the game just fails to communicate the worth of this at all?)

The natural affinity is to play wide and capture as much land as possible. This is inherently neither good nor bad. But they want to make tall playstyles also viable, and much of what has been done to facilitate this just makes the game annoying. All sorts of arbitrary restrictions and debuffs for being successful.

Achievements only work on ironman mode aka NO SAVING. Oh but even on fastest speed games take many hours, I'm sure this wont be a problem.

There is a lot of notification spam. Every little thing is a popup you have to stop and deal with. Many pause the game for you. Items such as "random empires you have never heard about did something" are as important as a scientist doing an expendition or a research finishing. There are thousands of popups each game. By the half way mark i can barely even be bothered to read the lore snippets, I just want to play the game but have to read a book in stead.

Management of pops and planets is neat in principle, but gets very tedious very quickly. Some of this looks to change in 4.0 so i will not elaborate further.

With the price, mind the long list of DLC where most new stuff seems to have migrated to, it's just a bit too hard to recommend right now.

185884215.review:
Stellaris ist ein herausragendes Spiel, das die Grenzen des Strategiespiels neu definiert. Besonders hervorzuheben ist die exzellente Modunterstützung, die es den Spielern ermöglicht, ihre eigenen kreativen Ideen und Visionen in das Spiel einzubringen. Die Community hat eine beeindruckende Vielzahl von Mods entwickelt, die das Gameplay erweitern, neue Inhalte hinzufügen und das Spielerlebnis insgesamt bereichern.

Dank der Modding-Tools können Spieler nicht nur bestehende Inhalte anpassen, sondern auch völlig neue Mechaniken, Rassen und Geschichten erschaffen. Dies sorgt für eine nahezu unendliche Vielfalt und hält das Spiel frisch und spannend, selbst nach vielen Stunden Spielzeit. Die Möglichkeit, die eigene Erfahrung individuell zu gestalten, macht Stellaris zu einem besonders einladenden und dynamischen Universum.

Insgesamt ist Stellaris nicht nur ein fantastisches Strategiespiel, sondern auch eine Plattform für kreative Entfaltung. Die Modunterstützung ist ein entscheidender Faktor, der das Spiel zu einem Muss für jeden Fan des Genres macht. Ich kann es nur wärmstens empfehlen!

185883727.review:
J'ai beaucoup aimé ce jeu par le passé.
Il y a énormément de bonnes idées et les parties peuvent être très fun.

Cependant il y a des défauts majeurs que je ne peux plus ignorer:

- Le prix et le nombre de DLC, aujourd'hui soit on prends un abonnement mensuel à 10 balles soit on prends tous les 3 mois un DLC à 20 balles, ça commence à faire particulièrement cher pour un jeu qui a 9 ans. Je pense en particulier aux personnes qui découvrent aujourd'hui le jeu et qui se voient bloquées par des dizaines de DLC qui devraient être inclus dans le jeu de base à ce stade, même si l'option de l'abonnement est une solution c'est temporaire.

- La qualité plus que discutable des dernières mises à jour.
Le dernier DLC a ajouté une énorme quantité de bugs et mécaniques à moitié terminées, il y a même une quête principale d'une des nouvelles origines qui était IMPOSSIBLE à terminer, la quête se bloquait toute seule. (je sais pas si ce bug est corrigé aujourd'hui mais le fait qu'il n'ait pas été repéré pendant le développement en dit beaucoup sur le processus de développent des derniers DLC). 
Et c'est sans parler des mécaniques purement absentes: on a eu de quoi modifier génétiquement de la faune spatiale et aussi de quoi en faire des zombies avec deux mécaniques différentes mais alors POURQUOI les deux mécaniques n’interagissent pas ensemble? Pourquoi on ne peut pas modifier les zombies alors que les textes de lore du jeu laissent penser que c'est clairement possible?
Je ne vais pas faire le tour de chaque problèmes liés aux dernières mises à jour, ça serait trop long, mais vous comprenez où je veux en venir.

- Les problèmes d'optimisation.
Là c'est simple, le jeu n'est pas bien optimisé, les fins de parties sont exponentiellement plus lentes à mesure que les différents empires se développent. La manière dont les IA gèrent leurs flottes par exemple est une énorme source de lag.
Et ou je sais ce que vous allez me dire "prends un meilleur pc" sauf que le jeu recommende pas plus que 4go de RAM et une vielle carte graphique pour le faire tourner, c'est pas avec mes 16go de RAM, une RTX 3060 et un plutôt bon proco que c'est censé lagger comme ça.
Le truc c'est que les recommendations sont fait selon ce que le jeu consomme en début de partie, pas en fin, ce qui et systématiquement différent dans les 4x, c'est le cas dans énormément de jeux similaires comme CIV par exemple.
De plus ces problèmes s'ajoutent à un multijoueur très instable ce qui rend l’expérience très désagréable entre les lags et les désynchro.

- IA Générative.
LE truc qui m'a décidé à ne plus jouer au jeu, tous les autres défauts j'aurais pu les accepter, râler un peu mais pas au point de ne plus jouer du tout, mais là je c'est ma limite absolue.
Dans le dernier DLC les devs ont, selon la page de ce dernier, utilisés une IA générative pour les aider dans leur processus créatif.
Les IA génératives sont un énorme tas de problèmes divers et variés sur tout un tas de sujet: écologie, droits humains, respect des artistes, colonialisme etc...
Utiliser, même un tout petit peu, une IA générative volontairement c'est participer activement au problème, n'y voir qu'une excuse pour pondre du contenu payant plus rapidement encore (parce que oui, en 2024 il y a eu 3 DLC sur une très courte période, si vous vous demandiez comment ça a pu arriver vous savez maintenant).
Les soucis techniques des dernières mises à jours sont liés à cette cadence accélérée de développement et l'utilisation d'IA générative est une excuse pour cut toujours plus de temps de développement.
Donc même si vous en avez rien à foutre de cramer la planète ou de pisser sur les droits humains, même d'un point de vue purement égoïste le fait que ce jeu utilise de l'IA générative vous donne un contenu moins bon.

N'achetez pas ce jeu.
Il y en a tout un tas d'autres qui font mieux ce que celui là prétend faire et qui respecte réellement ses joueurs.

Je précise que je garderais un oeil sur le jeu, si les devs font quelque chose pour changer leurs manière de développer, si les problèmes cités sont réglés, peut être que je retirerais cet avis négatif, cependant je ne me fait pas trop de faux espoirs.

185875996.review:
Stellaris is probably the best grand strategy/ 4X game i have ever played, it has an impressive ability to pull you into it and keep you playing for hours at a time; This is a game is great if you want to RP or if you want to min/max and win. The game is consistently supported with major updates, patches and DLCs with each x.0 update bringing massive changes that keep the game fresh. The modding community is also incredibly skilled, with many mods having incredibly high quality with a lot of passion put into them. (certainly better then the mods i see for civ 6)
The main issue that i take with the game is that the DLCs are numerous, expensive, lock out important features and are often of questionable quality, especially the non-mechanical DLCs, essentially all of them are very questionable, though thankfully the worst ones tend to not lock away mechanics. The performance of the game is quite poor late game, especially if you are modding but this is seeming to be getting some fixes in the 4.0 update so take that comment with a grain of salt once it comes out.
I would rate the game 8/10, it is very fun and worth it if you enjoy grand strategy games, but the DLCs are a major issue

So this is exactly the type of multiple month game time negative review that gets screen shot and memed on social media, but I'm sad to say I mean it in the most literal sense.  I have enjoyed much of my play time with Stellaris, but I emphatically don't recommend anyone purchase this game in it's current, maximum DLC form.
When this game launched, it was a refreshingly basic 4X. Most of the changes made in the early years all the way to the Nemesis expansion added meaningfully to the gameplay without making it overwhelming and complicated for new players.  Unfortunately recent patches and expansions have unfortunately been hats on hats, mostly adding complexity without adding fun.  I have enjoyed the ride for the most part, but like most Paradox games the continual addition of DLC eventually replaces the game you loved with something you barely recognize while draining your wallet.

185730471.review:
Space. 
Tech. 
Research.
Physics.
It's like Civ - but in space. 
What is not to like!!! 
Well a bit actually, but generally the negativity is focused on one element: 
The basic fundamental design flaws with the menus and getting x to do y. Nothing can be designed that counter-intuitive by accident! 
You will waste hours, if not days, making mistakes that are, in massive part, down that counter-intuitive menu system and the single click options that should have been made available on a certain screen but isn't. 
But that is my main gripe with it. 

Overlook the slightly annoying interface and it's a really enjoyable Civ-like 'big' strategy game. 

There's just about enough information in the 'tutorial', albeit it's presented in a very odd way. It's enough to launch you beyond the solar system. After that the search engine of your choice is your friend and you will get RSI from typing "Stellaris, how do I [insert what it is you can't do]". 
You will find your answers. 
Just it could have been so much easier, had the designers done a walk-through watching newcomers play.
Games are often like films or TV series - if the first half hour is appalling and you don't know what the fridge is going on then you're not likely to continue. 
Stellaris just about made it through the first 30 minutes. 
The minor gripe that I have is all the expansions cost a lot of money. I've no idea if I need any of them - but my starting experience happened to be with Utopia & Apocalypse. I'll think about buying some if they're heavily discounted.

185722044.review:
Yes, the DLC mountain can be daunting, yes not every DLC hits the mark and I understand that. 

However.

After 2300 hours of Vanilla (maybe 20 hours of Gigastructures) There is still enough in this game to keep me going for another 2500 hours, the sheer scale of whats possible never ceases to amaze me and I play it mostly as a Roleplayer, I may not make the best decisions, I don't always take the best tech or have the best ships.

But that's whats great about Stellaris, it literally doesn't matter how you play the game, just that you have fun! Winning your 400th war feels just as good as your first, becoming the Galactic Custodian always gives me a buzz and when you're facing down the End Game Crisis backed by your multiple fleets only for a random federation of AI to use this chance to settle old scores with another federation is just AMAZING!

Yes, some of the changes they've made and are planning to make will, once again, upset the balance of things and we all wait for Montu to release a new updated guide but that'salso the beauty of Stellaris, its never the same playthrough twice!

185439597.review:
Welcome to the Endless Void of... Addictive Space Micromanagement

Stellaris is the game where you start as a humble species with dreams of greatness, only to realize you're one wrong diplomatic choice away from being devoured by intergalactic bug monsters or enslaved by sentient AI. And honestly? I love it.

The galaxy is vast, the possibilities are endless, and so is the learning curve. Seriously, if you thought calculus was tough, wait until you're juggling fleet logistics, planetary management, trade routes, and the existential dread of accidentally awakening a Fallen Empire. But hey, that’s half the fun! The other half is yelling at your screen when your "trustworthy" allies backstab you five minutes after signing a non-aggression pact.

The DLC? It’s like an uncharted galaxy itself—daunting and expensive. But when you catch a sale, it feels like you've just discovered a rich system full of energy credits. That said, Stellaris without DLC is still an incredible game, just one where you feel like you're eating pizza without all the toppings. Still good, but you know there’s more out there.

Overall, if you love spreadsheets, strategy, and the sheer chaos of trying to manage a galactic empire while wondering how the Blorg Friendship Force managed to outperform your military, this is your game. It's a glorious mix of "just one more turn" and "wait, where did my fleet go?"

Final Score: 8.7/10
Would accidentally trigger an endgame crisis again.

185390254.review:
The game has the potential to be great, but Paradox is too busy pumping out DLC to address a plethora of core usability issues, many of which are only experienced well into the game.

Planetary management is fine when you are just starting out with a few planets, but when you have hundreds its a problem. There is an automation feature, but it won't do what you want it to do because of inadequate customization. So you have a ton of tedious and pointless micromanagement or leave it up to vassal or planetary AI, which isn't ideal. They could include a planetary build templates feature, but they still haven't done so years later.

Influence is an arbitrary resource which overly constricts too many aspects of the game, from warfare to internal government. You can use a total war system which doesn't require influence, but that is arbitrarily locked behind late game planet killer technology. You need influence to do an ever increasing amount of actions, and yet you only get a small amount of influence which can't be significantly increased like the rest of your economy.

There are also a variety of annoying arbitrary limits. If your civilization has the resources to build multiple Dyson spheres, why shouldn't you be allowed to? Why can you only build a limited number of starbases?

Besides the problems with the core game mechanics, the software itself is also quite buggy. On Windows 11 the game crashes constantly. On Ubuntu Linux the pointer is tiny.

185313307.review:
There is a lot wrong with this game that I don't like, which I will cover below. I definitely don't recommend buying this game unless it is on a major sale.

Cons:
- Achievements: in order to get achievements on Steam, you are forced to play in "Ironman" mode, where you cannot manually save the game to quit whenever you want. This is a huge deal to someone like me, who loves collecting achievements in games, and also because I need to step away from the computer quite often. This is by far the BIGGEST thing I dislike about this game.
- DLC hell: there are too many DLC packs each costing a lot, even when there are discount sales it is still way too much in my opinion to fully collect every pack for this game.
- Poorly designed tutorials: the tutorials are all written and while some have voice lines, they do not highlight what you are supposed to click on. I had to Google numerous different mechanics in order to figure out how to apply them as there were no highlighted visuals. Examples include how to create new sectors, how to figure out how to build observation posts, etc. As a visual learner, I would have preferred the tutorial highlight where these buttons are, rather than having to watch YouTube videos for more than 10 mins at a time to explain otherwise not so complex functions.
- Difficulty levels on easiest mode not being easy: I noticed when playing the game on the easiest setting on both Ironman and regular modes, the system AI had NPC's with score in the 50k+ range and my best at 3rd place was 6-7k. I do not understand why the AI NPC's are so powerful in the victory count, especially on beginner difficulty! Not a fan.
- Graphics not as good as store advertised: even zoomed in, space doesn't look that good, and you play most of the game zoomed out at max. Honestly underwhelming and not the best to look at, compared to other games where space is more detailed.

Pros:
- I like the concept, and think if executed better it would be a great game for sure.
- I got the base game on sale for under $10.
- The designs of the different species are cool.

Overall, I just am disappointed. In other city builders such as the Civilization series, the beginner difficulties don't have such overpowered AI, in addition to better tutorials and achievements can be earned in any mode and difficulty unless otherwise specified. My main complaints are the achievement system and DLC hell.

185239610.review:
Im not a 4X kinda guy but I've spent a few hundred hours in Civ 6 so I thought I would give this a go. It sucks. I didn't buy the DLC but I shouldn't need to. I gave this two legitimate tries but the same problems come up. Go get Civ 6, not because its great, but because it's free on Epic, and it's better than this trash.

To start, the game's tutorials just tell you that you can do something. Great. What would they affect? Who knows!? The only way to learn most things is by consulting a wiki. Is this large empire that is multiple hours of micromanagement away from me in terms of power important? Can I become their ally? Are they neutral? There is just no way to tell. What does this civic do? How do I research what I want from the tech tree? The game just doesn't tell you. You have to google the answer and find out that the tech tree isn't really a tree but a rotating set of options that are RANDOM. You also have to look up how to please certain empire types because depending on their ethics, they like or are open to different actions, none of which you can learn without looking it up first. 

Second, the game is very unbalanced. sure, for a pro it might be too easy, but any game will be that way. The new player experience on default settings, choosing a default empire will lead them down a bad time. Why do 2 empires start with more research done than me? why do 2 OTHER empires start AT THE END OF THE TECH TREE. That's right, when you make a game on default settings two empires will start with every technology researched, and will be nearly impossible for a casual enjoyer of the game unless they know about them, and prepare for them from the first minute of the game. This then runs into the issue of the game not explaining what other empires like. One of the mega-empires can hate you for claiming a system near them(when the beginning of a game is nothing BUT a land-grab race for all empires), but the game doesn't let you know that, and as such they will obliterate you for trying. Then there is a timer on your game. Why a timer? Because the devs needed a way to challenge experienced players. There is something called "the crisis" that will destroy you unless you knew about it beforehand and prepared all game, much like the empires at the end of the tech tree would.

Then there is the diplomacy system. I don't know how they managed it, but its even worse than Civ 6's. If you want to do ANYTHING productive, you need to have great relations with an empire. This is because all of your options, other than giving them free materials are not available unless you're on good relations with them. This also bleeds into combat, where declaring war makes you select a specific war goal, which NEEDS to be achieved to win. You have to somehow force the AI to surrender which it will never do, or after you go to war for a while you get something common in 4X games. War weariness. This happens during any combat for both sides. But in this game, once it hits 100%, YOU AUTO-ACCEPT A STATUS QUO. This means  the enemy can take your stars quickly at the start, get you to a 100% war exhaustion (because they took your stars), and as soon as you get a force capable of reclaiming those stars moved over to take them back, the other empire can force you to make peace and surrender them. The war wasn't over, the fighting didn't stop, and even if you had the strength to wipe out the enemies completely, because they attacked first and took undefended stars (of which you'll have a lot of because the map is huge), you are forced to give them up. This is so dumb I cannot believe that a whole company thought of this, said it was a good idea, and left it in the game for a decade. This seems like something in a prototype when you can't figure out any interesting war mechanics so you shove this garbage in there. Also the Galactic Federation is absolutely useless, as nearly all of the resolutions to vote on in the galactic senate mean absolutely nothing and change almost nothing. Most of the time, the empires proposing them don't even benefit from the proposed legislation so it doesn't make any sense on why they would propose it. I have even seen a large empire I was at war with propose a legislation that would increase the upkeep on military, and this bankrupted them and effectively removed them from the game, because they couldn't afford to make a new fleet after that.

Don't even get me started on the gameplay decisions, there is only a single way to play the game! It's domination victory or nothing! There is culture, but past mid game, it can't even help you! And while the current ways to win the game would technically be considered science victories, they require you to dominate every other empire, because they will all turn on you once you go for the victories anyway. And the way battles work is horrible. It's literally just bigger number = win. Sometimes the win is so egregious that my 5k fleet will destroy a 4.9k fleet with no losses at all. This leads to the main strategy being to get a large deathball so the enemy you are fighting will always be too weak to take on your fleet and removes any sort of interesting plays you could make. This is made even worse by the map, which is a grid of stars that are connected, but only in certain directions. This leads to many obvious choke points which become impassible obstacles once you take the simple action of moving every military related thing to that choke point. Even the AI knows it can't beat you doing that and will mass fleets right next to the choke point, but if your number is larger than theirs, you just move out and kill them before their number is larger than yours, and they will never be able to field a large enough fleet to destroy you unless they started with one.

Finally, for some reason, half the UI is also broken, and when you decide to do something the buttons just don't do anything. In the fleet manager, you can't design a fleet to be your ideal army. You have the option to copy a fleet, but not save one as a template to keep, so when the fleet dies, you have to make it from scratch, clicking in all the different ships you want to have 1-by-1, but if it doesn't die, you can do that automatically with the Copy Fleet button. Then there is districts on planets that only allow so many. Trying to add another will not let you, and it won't even disable the button, it just doesn't queue a district for you. The only way to know you are over in districts is to manually count them, or to hover over the little squares, where a popup will show the number of that type of district, then after 5 seconds of loading, show you your total distinct amount.

The sad fact that this came out in 2016 makes me wonder if video games will ever be decent again, because most of the systems in this game feel like placeholders, or half-implementations. It's a game that isn't even a mile wide but it's still only an inch deep.

185153588.review: 其玩法丰富多元，涵盖了资源管理、科技研发、外交周旋以及星际战争等多个维度，每一个决策都可能引发蝴蝶效应，带来截然不同的发展路径，为玩家提供了极高的策略自由度。画面精美绝伦，浩瀚宇宙、奇异星球与炫酷飞船等元素共同构建出一个令人神往的科幻世界，搭配上契合场景的优质音效，沉浸感十足。尽管游戏存在新手教程繁琐、后期容易陷入重复的问题，但瑕不掩瑜。它凭借宏大的世界观、复杂的策略体系以及深度的游戏机制，成功地为玩家打造出一片充满无限可能的星际舞台，让玩家得以尽情施展自己的战略才华，是策略游戏中的上乘之作，值得深入探索。

185147171.review:
Do you have a noisy neighbor who won’t stop bugging you? The answer is simple:

Neutron bombardment!

Stellaris is one of the games that I constantly return to, time and time again. The gameplay itself is *stellar*, but the stories that the game (and your imagination) plays out between different factions vying for control of the cosmos are what makes this game worth your money.

Compared to Civilization’s historical empires, the ability to fully create your own stellar empire with it’s own history can’t be beat.

Now, there are an excessive amount of DLCs - some that, after playing with them, feel essential to the game, and some that… Well, you get the picture.

My best advice? Buy those DLCs one at a time, on sale. Oh, and neutron bombardment.

185109238.review:
A surprisingly well-done balance between complexity and accessibility.

Of course, don't touch this if you are not looking for a fairly deep game. It has a lot of stuff you can fiddle with to optimize your stellar empire, but as I said: It turns out that many things work reasonably well by themselves and can be ignored or automated. Micro-managing your empire will give you an advantage, but for the first few games, it'll work just fine without.

That said, Stellaris delivers on the promise. It's a 4X space game with tons of systems and options and a great amount of freedom on how to play.

The one thing that I seriously dislike is the sheer amount of DLCs.

Es waren ein paar witzige Stunden, die Mechaniken auszuprobieren und in der Hinsicht ist es komplex und macht Spaß. Man kann wirklich auf den Spielverlauf Einfluss nehmen und dabei ganz unterschiedliche Ansätze verfolgen. 
Wenn es jedoch um das Übernehmen von anderen Systemen geht, also Krieg, wirds (bleibts?) ziemlich zäh. Man braucht Geduld und es ist nicht wirklich Action. Wäre ein schöner Ausgleich zum sonst eher trockenen Geschehen. 
Außerdem kann die KI Dinge, die man als Spieler nicht kann + die KI muss sich nicht an die Gesetzmäßigkeiten halten, die man als Spieler befolgen muss.
Es ist ein paar Stunden witzig, wenn man das Genre mag.... aber eigentlich ein Sturm im Wasserglas. Und manches Add-On, zum Beispiel diese Stürme, bringen einfach nur wahllos zusätzliche Komplikationen. Also nichts, was ich langfristig spielen oder empfehlen würde.

185048320.review:
Es mas facil de lo que parece, PERO siempre que hayas aprendido todo jajaja, es un juego que tiene mucha informacion y gran parte de esta no te la explican o no me he enterado y llegar a la conclusion de como funciona cierta estadistica puede ser frustrante.

El juego se basa en explorar y conquistar estrellas (sistemas solares) y colonizar planetas para expandir tu poblacion, con esto poder formar flotas y pelear con otros jugadores o bots, que no os hecha para atras el tema de los bots, tienen varias dificultades y mucha personalizacion de partidas, estamos jugando en la dificultad "normal" si no mal recuerdo y es suficientemente desafiante sin ser injusto (aunque a veces ocurren cosas bastante wtf) en este caso a mi lo que me fastidia es que los recursos de los bots no son realistas, o incluso en una dificultad muy baja tienen mucho boost, con la persona que juego habitualmente hemos llegado a ver un imperio que tiene 4 o 5 estrellas y 2 planetas con los mismos o mas recursos que un jugador con >20 estrellas y 8  planetas... Eso da pie a que tengan unas tropas/defensas mucho mas fuertes de lo que deberia, incluso un jugador normal da la sensacion de que en ese estado no podria generar tantos recursos.

Sobre el tema de los recursos, para mi gusto está bien, tienes 4 o 5 principales y con eso puedes avanzar bastante en la partida, cuando quieras equipacion mejor has de desbloquear ciertos materiales que son mas escasos pero te permiten tener mas poder, eso es obvio, pero hablando desde un punto de vista de alguien que he llegado a tener una partida con media galaxia casi (dificultad reducida a la normal) no he podido generar tantos materiales de esos especiales como para que todas mis flotas estén maxeadas, no se si lo hice mal pero no encontraba la forma de aumentar la produccion.

Sobre el tema de recursos seré breve, se consiguen principalmente con estaciones mineras en sistemas solares o con edificios especificos en planetas, bastante comodo para no tener que estár pensando en donde buscarlos.

Sobre el tema de los planetas tengo un dilema de amor/odio, se nota que es el core del juego (opinion personal) son bastante complicados de estabilizar hasta que aprendes lo que significan xx numeros de estadisticas, para mi gusto falta algunos ajustes para poder visualizar mejor las cosas para no tener que darte cabezazos contra la mesa o tener que gastar muchas horas para acabar aprendiendolo, se puede hacer mas comoda la informacion, no obstante hay mods que lo permiten (por algo será que la gente crea estos tipos de mods...) desgraciadamente si juegas con gente, todos han de tener los mismos mods activos, ni siquiera se pueden tener mods del lado [CLIENTE] ya que internamente cambia la version del juego y ya no te deja unirte a una partida lo cual lo veo bastante estupido ya que no provoca nada malo.

En general es un juego entretenido con un arte muy bonito y una gestion de recursos sencilla; siempre y cuando le dediques al menos 60h o 30h investigando y no jugando improvisando.

Lo recomiendo especialmente con el DLC de megaestructuras, paara mi gusto tiene la especie mente colmena que me está encantando. Con rebajas obvimente o en paginas de terceros :)

Tampoco recomiendo crear tu propio imperio personalizado pese a que parezca facil, a lo largo de la partida se te puede ir al traste completamente sin saber por que.

Calculo que jugaré otras 150-250h antes de necesitar un parón grande del juego.

185046735.review: My favourite game ever, if you have the time and money, and like grand strategy games, this one is a masterpiece, if youre a new player for the non discount price of 40 euros youll have 50 to 100 hours of fun gameplay, then learn the game basics and realise 90% of the fun stuff from trailers is locked away in DLCs. DLCs are really just big optimized mods and most of them are highly overprized and mostly include stuff that shoudve been just regular updates. The bundle with them costs around 200 euros and i understand the devs need money but sometimes i feel like they push it a bit too much. I highly reccomend to everyone interested to check out DLC guides and tier lists aswell because you mostly need just 3 to have the full game with base trailer content (Utopia, Apocalypse, Overlord are essentials if you wanna have fun as a long time player, these three you can get for 60 ish euros without any discounts, so the true price of base game is actually 100 euros, otherwise it doesnt feel complete). If any devs read this PLEASE somehow fix multiplayer with preset empires or small competitive arenas and tournaments for example, this is just meta hunting and its sweatier than me on a hot summer day.

184864101.review:
Eu já havia jogado alguns jogos de estrategia como Age of Empires, SuperPower e Command and Conquer, e esse é até agora o que eu mais gostei. Primeiramente, porque ele tem várias facetas, é um jogo 4X (eXplorar, eXpandir, eXtrair, eXterminar), então obviamente ele se demonstra complexo, além disso é uma ficção cientifica muito cativante, ou seja, ele é muito profundo na história, tendo tanto temas políticos, científicos, sociais e etc, o que deixa tudo muito rico. Este jogo também recebe constantemente atualizações de correção de bugs e balanceamento, o que faz a comunidade tender a ficar mais engajada, também é bem otimizado.
Mas é claro que nem tudo são flores, então vou falar alguns pontos negativos: O jogo é muito caro, então pegue em uma promoção que ai sim vai valer muito a pena. Outro, muitas dlcs interessantes mas muito caras e divididas em várias. Ele é obviamente nichado devido aos outros pontos que eu disse acima, o que torna ele muito bom, mas ao mesmo tempo difícil de convencer algum amigo a jogar ou encontrar uma partida, mas é claro que você pode jogar singleplayer sem problema. 
E por último, pode ser difícil de aprender a jogar, o tutorial ajuda e há vários fãs que disponibilizam dicas e guias, mas ainda assim pode ser complicado compreender tudo. Porém nenhum aspecto e mecânica do jogo parece exagero e todos fazem sentido, faz você passar o tempo e também exercitar os neurônios que você já não usa pra nada mesmo. Enfim, recomendo.

184860795.review:
The aggressive type that only play as fanatic militarists and xenophobes ruin the image of the game honestly. I've seen it gain somewhat of a reputation for it being HOI4 in space with a crowd that's just as bad. I really wish people wouldn't see it that way.

As fun as playing like that is (I'm guilty of it), there's so much more to do. My current save is playing as a custom empire which is basically the Flood from Halo. I'm basically roleplaying as mindless creatures who infect everything they see and attack on sight. Admittedly that probably feeds into the issue I mentioned BUT, my last save 
was far more interesting and tame. 

I roleplayed as a civilization that went through a brutal civil war and was "saved" by a prophet of sorts and ascended into ultra-religious and biologically advanced beings. I even wrote that in my empire's lore (Yes, there's a custom lore section but it's more for fun than anything). I then kept getting contacted by the "prophet" until I explored a wormhole in my home system that transported me to a an empire long forgotted to time which turned out to be where the prophet was from and they congratulated me on coming to find them while telling me they were watching over me the whole time. Then I ended up in a really bad war which could've led to the complete erasure of my empire. BUT MY OVERLORDS HELPED ME AND FOUGHT FOR MY SURVIVAL. We held celebrations on every planet I owned and we made it a national holiday (celebrate it or GET OUT). 

There's so much to do in the game. If you're not the roleplay type and you just want to start and play whatever, you don't even have to. Just make a nation that fits what you wanna do and then you're free to play how you want. The game even gives you premade options for nations to start as if you don't wanna do that.

I advise starting with the "Starter Edition" since it comes with neat DLC addons. If you like the game then you could start getting DLC but there's like $250 worth so try not to spend all your money in one place. I got the Ultimate Bundle during the Christmas sale for $100. Definitely hurt my wallet but it's beautiful

This is a proper mess of a game. Far too many systems intertwined and updating constantly. Every time I start up a new game which lasts an absurd amount of hours, I have to relearn what has changed in the months prior. Over the years some mechanics were pulled out of the base game and updated, modified how they work, made more important, and then resold as a small expansion. So, without a lot of the add-ons, the game can have broken interfaces which reference things you may not have. It is a Paradox game, and this constant support and updating is why I became a fan of the company. I know they'll keep making their games better post-launch.

184771054.review:
I recently picked up this game along with several modules on sale. (I’ll list my DLC below.)

In a nutshell, the game is an RTS RPG 4X strategy game. Your perspective is not explicitly outlined, but it is somewhat like you are an artificial intelligence that oversees high-level decisions for your civilization. You give ship orders, direct what planets to colonize, manage the economy, take action against threats, and make choices at key decision points.

For low-level management, you assign leaders to various positions like ship captains and planetary governors. The length of your game will encompass centuries, so leaders will suffer attrition from retirement or death. (This is why I describe your role as being like a guiding artificial intelligence, since leaders die of old age, but not you.)

Individual leaders have particular skills that influence where you assign them, and though they can learn new skills over their careers, they can sometimes develop negative traits. (Only a couple times did I find it necessary to reassign a leader to make their negative trait irrelevant.)

The mechanics have depth that you will be feeling your way through as you play. When there was something in particular that I needed to understand, either Reddit or YouTube had an answer for me.

Overall, the manner of expansion and exploration feels much like being within a Star Trek universe. You need science vessels to survey systems before you can claim them. So, I found it useful to have multiple science vessels, one for each direction of expansion, with one extra ship for analyzing anomalies.

As you develop trade routes, pirates can become an issue that need to be suppressed using your fleets. However, rather than involve my main fleets, I found that having several small flights of ships were effective when patrolling trade route sections.

My Stellaris DLC:
	• Utopia
	• Apocalypse
	• Leviathans Story Pack
	• Synthetic Dawn Story Pack
	• Distant Stars Story Pack
	• Ancient Relics Story Pack
	• First Contact Story Pack
	• Humanoids Species Pack

184769291.review:
As someone who has played thousands of hours of other Paradox games, namely EU4/CK3/V3, this game feels familiar yet very different. I find the early-mid game fun and engaging, exploring and surveying, uncovering the mysteries of the universe is a great way to spend a few hours. At this point though most of the universe is controlled by you and AI empires. 

This is when the game starts to suck. Diplomacy is bare bones, limited to options such as trade, defensive pact, knowledge share etc. The AI empires don't feel very alive or interesting. Federations and the galactic community don't add much in the way of interest either, just different user interfaces for much the same things as before. 

War is where things really take a nose dive though. Space battles on an individual level are fine and the combat animations are nice enough. But warfare is one element of the game without any automation, so when you are at war with several empires, be prepared to click a thousand times to move your fleet around. Often painfully chasing other fleets, which feels like a slug chasing a snail. 

I should add that I only have the base game without any DLC. This is the only Paradox game I havent purchased from the beginning, which means I'd have to spend several hundred dollars to get content which could make the game worthwhile. But as we know, games shouldn't have to be hundreds of dollars to be enjoyable. 

I don't recommend this game and I don't recommend the Paradox way of locking content behind paywalls.

184687173.review:
This felt like one of those movies that started out really great, but halfway through gets derailed... and you keep with it because the first half had such promise... but then it never delivers and you're left disappointed.
 The first part of the game was great. Exploring around and claiming new systems, watching the border of your civilization grow in increments. The feeling of urgency, trying outrace the other civilizations for claim on this or that. Developing your research, and building your fleets. It was exciting finding new planets that were habitable, and sending colony ships to establish new worlds. There was this great feeling that it was all leading somewhere.
After borders are established, you find yourself asking, "Hmmm, what now?" This isn't a problem for too long, as there is diplomacy to consider, colonies to develop, ships to design, fleets to build, outposts to be fortified. It's all leading up to something...

From diplomacy to trading this game claims to have it all. except after about 25 hours you'll realize it offers all these things at the most superficial level. Here's Diplomacy: You can improve relations, which doesn't really do anything except make them willing to trade, or maybe eventually become your vassal. Sounds cool, right? Except they never want to trade resources on a monthly basis, which eliminates the usefulness of diplomacy altogether. You can do individual trades, where I'll give you X of this for X of that, but it's absolutely tedious to do so. When you're dealing with over 20k units of a resources, it would be nice to be able to just type into the text field "20000". Nope. You gotta sit there and click to increase the amount by 100 at a time. So, if you want to trade 20k energy credits for X amount of dark matter, you have to sit there and click, click, click, click. And that's just for once resource in the trade. Say you want to trade 5 or 6 different things.. Click, click, click.. The whole process makes trading so tedious, and half the time I'm just trying to get rid of resources or gain favor with whoever I'm trading with.
Except gaining favor doesn't matter. It benefits you in no way to gain favor with other civilizations. Doesn't offer you resources. They can become your vassal, except if they do it literally doesn't affect you at all. You don't get access to their resources, and if you do... or something does happen... it's not obvious to the point that a first time player would notice.
And that's what you begin to realize after 40 hours. Nothing you do outside of managing your resources really matters. You uplifted a species into sentience? Cool. It doesn't affect anything except you get to read some pop-ups about their progress. If it adds a new race to your civilization, I didn't notice. By 40 hours I had tons of different species roaming around. But here's the thing: I had no sense of that. There's all this stuff supposedly happening, but no visual representation of it actually happening. I know that's probably too much to ask for in a simulation of this scope, but my mind goes to games like roller coaster tycoon or Theme park, or even Sim City and Rimworld, where you can SEE the progress you're making, you can see the little models roaming around your creation. Here you can't tell what your pops are doing... how they're living... it's all just a few words of text that left me feeling disconnected and dispassionate about what I was building.

It was just a bunch of symbols on a world map, and numbers corresponding to your resources. And the resource mechanics, while not difficult to balance, aren't exactly clear either. You build a new district or building, but the effects don't immediately take place. They go up after a "tic" or two. When you have about 20 different colonies to manage, and all types of buildings and districts are going up at once, it's hard to gauge exactly how resources will fluctuate. Sometimes i'd see drastic changes, once having a massive surplus and the next operating at a deficit. Sure, I could have paid more attention to all the details of upkeep and how much this or that costs... but there seriously is information overloading going on, and at some point you just want to get on with it. After a while I felt like I wasn't playing an empire simulator, but rather just an economy simulator. Constantly jumping between screens to build this or that.
And that's another thing that started to drive me nuts after a while. You can't unpause the game for longer than 5 seconds without being overwhelmed by notifications. You get pinged with a new notification so often that it's nearly impossible to focus on the task at hand. You're constantly distracted by something, and it left me feeling like I'd forgotten something, or something else needed tending to. 

So diplomacy is hollow... that leaves us with war, right?  Surely spending a couple hours designing many different ship loadouts with all the fancy new toys I researched ought to lead to some fun, right? So now let's pick a fight with my belligerent neighbor who keeps talking smack.  I waged war on him, completely overwhelming his puny ship designs with my superior fleet. I took system after system, eventually subjugating the rude birds under my rule.  Sounds fun, right? Not really. Here's combat in Stellaris: You spend several weeks or months of game time moving your fleets into position. You fan the flames of politics to justify the war... and then you launch your shock and awe campaign.
That first battle, I didn't know what to expect when I moved my fleet into range of the enemies fleet. The numbers representing the strength of their fleet were pitiful compared to my own, but still I was nervous. I had no idea how to command my corvettes, frigates, and destroyers. would it be like homeworld? 3d fuzzballs of spacewar mayhem?  Nope. 2d, and while visually cool, there was nothing more to it than watching a bunch of ships fly around zapping each other with light and missiles. Coulnd't tell who was who, and there was absolutely no input from me aside from a decision to retreat or not.  All it was was watching the numbers of the respective fleets go down until one was left standing.

Some will say that Stellaris was never designed to be tactical, and it's more of a strategy game. I kind of get their point... but the problem isn't even that it's not tactical, or player involved enough, it's that you can't even tell what's going on.

All the time I spent designing all kinds of ships, and I couldn't even tell which one was performing in action. I couldn't pick one out from the other, and had no idea what sort of effect each loadout was making on the battlefield. You know how you think something might work on paper, but in practice its totally different? You can't tell if that's the case here. You just load up your different ships however you want, but at the end it just equates to numbers on a screen, and you have no idea which weapons or combinations of weapons are performing effectively or not.

So, combat was definitely a flop. And the strategic side of the war wasn't really fun either. Just keep a fleet stationed in differect sectors of your domain. No real strategic thought to it whatsoever, except where to attack next. 

ON top of that, keeping your ships upgraded is absolutely tedious.  As soon as you re-outfit your entire fleet, a new upgrade comes along that requires you to go in and redesign all your ships--AGAIN.  And again. and again... and then your ships gotta go to a shipyard to get outfitted... so plan your wars around your next upgrade.  It's just tedious and annoying... altogether.. without even the benefit of a payoff.  Personally I think adding an option to fight a tactical battle or autoresolve could save this game, and then have some total war warhammer type battles, or battlefleet gothic style, or even homeworld style.  ANYTHING...

184687081.review:
I can recommend earlier guises of this game, but not with the latest upgrades (or a subscription that employs all of the upgrades).

I have hundreds of hours on this game (this account plus my old, deactivated one), and have been playing pretty much since this game came out.  And  while I was never good enough to post a how-to video, I generally always had fun.  

All the varying DLC packs have done is to make the game more busy and decidedly less fun.  

I used to conquer neighbours and build huge fleets to challenge them, which was fun.  Now, I have to work just to continuously build planets to supply one resource or another that I'm always running short on.  Not fun.

Another example is archaeological sites and establishing communications.  More unnecessary busy work that detracts from the game and adds no value.  Communications used to be automatic upon meeting another faction/race, now it's more "realistic" (and less fun) clicking your way to an inevitable contact scenario anyway.  They keep introducing more "middlemen" into each facet of the game, overly burdening the user.

I think the developers forgot that games are supposed to be mostly fun, not all work. 

If you're looking for fun, look elsewhere, or maybe get the more basic version.  If you're a nerd that likes doing spreadsheets in their spare time, get all the content and go for it.

Just today I saw the paradox support rep. refused the request from a Chinese player that supporting official Chinese.

就在今天，我看到了P社客服对一位玩家的官方中文请求表达了拒绝。

They said:

他们说：

'We sell our games to people in many many countries in the world, we can't localise for all of them. Aside from China we've had similar comments (in some cases demands) from Turkey, Japan, Russia, and others I can't think of right now.'

“我们游戏卖到了全世界，我们不能为每个国家都推出其语言。除了中国，我们还有来自土耳其，日本，俄罗斯以及其他我现在说不上来的国家的类似的评论（有时是需求）”

“我们的回答不变：我们的市场部门一直在评估所有国家的市场，以发掘推出本地化语言包是否可以带来经济效益；对于这些游戏来讲，至今为止似乎并不能。城市：天际线有中文版，如果你喜欢的话可以去玩。”

Firstly I must say that, for stellaris, Chinese players have contributed 100K sells, It's the fifth most purchase in all nations. 顺便我不太明白“城市天际线有中文，你喜欢可以去玩”是什么意思。大哥，人家卖了你们的游戏，然后人家在请求服务时候，你跟人家说你可以玩别的？我不觉得这话尊重一个玩家群体。你觉得我们只关注中文吗？不不不我们关注的是你们是否尊重这10万个买了游戏的人。

Eigentlich müsste ich eher nen mittleren Daumen vergeben, was nicht am Spiel selbst liegt.
Stellaris ist mit  großen  Abstand das beste Weltraum Scifi 4X Game was man sich vorstellen kann.
Allein die Erstellung der eigene Spezies, ist ein Traum für alle Scifi Fans. Du kannst nahezu jede Art von Volk erstellen was man so aus anderen Universen kennt. Nen brutales Terranisches Empire aller Warhammer, die komischen Parasitären Weltraumschlanngen aus Star Gate, eine Wohlwollende Föderation wie aus Star Trek. Oder lieber die Assimilierenden Borg?
Nen alles verschlingender Schwarm wie die Zerg, aus Starcraft, oder Tyraniden aus Warhammer?
Es gibt quasi kaum grenzen.

Die Diplomatie ist auch ziemlich gut, ich kann ganze Reiche standartmässig erobern, mit ihnen zusammen verschiedene Arten der Föderation gründen, oder sie per Diplomatie ganz in mein Reich einverleiben.
Vieleicht werd ich aber auch selbst einfach zu Galaxy vernichtenden Krise, oder zum Retter eben jeder vor dieser.

Also was das Spiel an sich angeht, geht der Daumen ganz klar nach oben, und es würde von mir ne 1+ bekommen müsste ich in Schulnoten Urteilen.


Ganz großes Minuspunkt ist allerdings die Performance im Endgame. Das Game läuft auch bei großen/Riesigen Glaxykarten (welche mir wegen der KI Viefalt halt am meisten Spaß machen) traumhaft. Im Endgame, wenn dann die Flotten größer werden, und die KI anfängt Habbitate zu spamen, und die Megastructuren zunehmen....geht das gelagge los.
In Friedenszeiten noch ertragbar, wird das ganze bei großen Kriegen durch Krisen fast unspielbar und zu nem reinen Lagfest.
Ich gehe auch nicht von aus das es an meinem Rechner liegt, weil er die empfohlenen Anforderungen noch übertrifft, und bei anderen Spielen nicht so einbricht. Sondern einfach davon das es im Endgma einfach zuviel wird was da berechnet werden muss.

まだ数分しかプレイしていない＆これ系を触るのが初めて勢ですが、
チュートリアルで挫折する人が絶対にいるゲームだなと感じました。

ほかの方のレビューにあるようにとにかくチュートリアルの作りがよくないと感じます。
初心者のためのチュートリアルなのに、肝心のチュートリアルが次にやるべきタスクに必要な
アイコンを強調表示することもなく膨大なアイコン、タブがある画面から探し出せと言われます。
せめてタスクに必要なアイコン以外をグレーで覆うなり強調表示するなりして欲しいです。
造船所から調査船を作ろうという最も序盤なチュートリアルでどうすればいいかわからず
画面をひたすらクリック。
しかし見つからない。
それが10分も続くと…やる気がなくなります。

たとえチュートリアルを越えられたとしても指示だけで精いっぱいなのに
指示なし一人でプレイできる自信がありません。
用語も多くチュートリアルを何週かしないとこのゲームの仕様を理解するのは
難しいだろうと想像ができてしまいました。
ハマれば楽しそうなゲームだったので残念です。

購入を考えている方及びこれ系のゲーム初めて触るよって方はセールで購入することと、
最新のレビューを見てから購入することをお勧めします。
セールしていないときの価格がフルプライスに劣らない値段のため、初手で詰みげーになってしまうと
お財布的に辛いですし、最新のレビューでは同じようにチュートリアルで難儀している方が多くみられます。
参考になるレビューだけを見て買わないようにしましょう。

同じような被害者が出てほしくないため上記を踏まえおすすめできません。

I bought this for 3 or 4 dollars on sale on Steam and still feel ripped off. The core concept of the game is good, but the implementation of it is poor. It's like a mobile game version of Civ5 in space but they rip out a bunch of the good parts and try to sell it to you for additional money. They hook you in with the cheap price of the base game, but don't mention that you need to pay like $100+ in DLC to get a good experience. If you want all the content then you are looking at $300+. 

Steam should honestly add a warning on this game that the DLC FAR outstrips the base price of this game. If you thought Destiny 2 was bad by using a similar tactic, this one is way worse IMO. You can faff about a lot. Devs keep upgrading parts of the game that suck so after playing it for years I can set it aside for a year or two pick it up and have a few fun new features.

The downsides are that it is a huge timesink and while some DLCs are nice, some are almost a must have for a fun game, some others are just a skin for your faction in case you want to give devs more money.

All in all a nice enough game that I ground almost 200 hours of my life away on it. I would say that the DLCs are a bit deer in price, and will admit that I have not, and also will not buy a single DLC for Stellaris for the full price. They are on sale often enough and one really does not need them too as much. They add to the game, but ya. Unless you are swimming in money or some crazy bundle is out, you can skip them for now and get a few after a year once you get bored and lo an behold a expanded experience.

184377161.review:
Honestly, I was disappointed with this game. I thought I would like it because it's a slow burn with deep game play elements. And I tried to give the game a fair shot. But the game has some issues that make progression not just difficult (even on the easiest settings) but downright unplayable. The problem is the randomness...

while playing, sometimes a random event will attack you out-of-the-blue or when you're in a position where you cannot response (usually both at the same time). This threat will be so large and so powerful that there is nothing you can do to stop it. And this is after building an empire for the last 15 hours. It's really disheartening and it's not like a cause-and-effect thing, it's just something that happens from time to time. Even on easy mode, I was attacked by a force that spawned inside of my territory that was 10x more powerful than me. and it just wrecked all of my ships, planets, space stations, and more. That incident killed the game for me in particular. 

There are also a lot of other small annoyances, like systems being hard to analyze at-a-glace, and combat being very basic.

All in all, I thought the game would be more well thought out, easier to understand, and still have an amazing depth to it. But all I was left with was disappointment and frustration.

184293447.review:
Stellaris has pretty positive reviews, but I think it's just winning by default in the "Master of Orion" style space 4X genre, and hardcore fans of that are overlooking a lot of flaws. There's not much competition besides smaller games by tiny indie studios. I'd only recommend this game to someone who wants to play that genre specifically, not someone who just wants a good game. Why?

1. Performance. This game is 8 years old but it still runs slowly. The coding was not done with optimization in mind at all. It should be fast.

2. Event results are important and opaque. They're not shown or easy to guess. This favors people who look them up online or memorized them. That's bad game design.

3. Too many shallow systems. You can design your own ships, but it's just putting the latest researched things in a few slots. You can manage planet economies, but all the incentives are towards dedicating each world to 1 resource type, so just do that.

4. Too much accumulation of tiny bonuses. +5% here, +10% here, sure it adds up, but the bonuses barely affect strategy. Instead of making the player want to do something different, they just average out into gradual overall improvements, with each individual bonus being forgettable.

5. It pushes DLC hard, and there's a lot of it. If you get the base game, it still shows all the items you can't use because you don't have that DLC yet. It's annoying and in poor taste.

184274179.review:
I feel like it's hard to review any Paradox game on it's own merits for two reasons:

One, all of them are - well no it'd be uncharitable to say they're all [i]the same[/i], each game does have its own idiosyncrasies and strengths. It's that once you've played 10 minutes of a paradox game you have more or less the broad experience of any of them. Queue up research, queue up buildings, turn on 4x speed and then wait for something to happen. It's not even that the waiting is particularly long or intolerable, it's just the fact it's the neutral state of the game, especially once you're efficient at setting up and automating early game. Sometimes nothing really interesting happens for minutes at a time and so it's hard to really review a game play loop that consists of around 50% waiting because whether everything else is worth the investment is almost wholly predicated on your tolerance for waiting. I tolerate it fine, but not a single friend I've gotten it for has been able to sit through even half a campaign. You're either the target demo or you're not and if you don't know if you are, you're probably not.  

Two, the other reason it's hard to review a paradox game is because infamously for their products about half of the game is scattered across ~40 DLC, making an accurate portrayal hard to nail down. Do I review only the base game even though that hasn't been my experience for years? Do I review the game in its entirety and give a complete view even if it means using the DLC packs I don't recommend? Or do I only talk about the ones I think are good and just let you figure out the rest? Which one of these is even the 'real' Stellaris?  It's easy to mislead people into thinking they'll necessarily have the same experience as I am describing out of the box, only to be disappointed when the space dragons are from a dlc, so I need to make sure I mention that. When I start needing to make a spreadsheet just to discuss the game to make sure I'm not lying to people about its content, I think that's another point against recommending it to people outside the community.

Now my issue isn't that the DLC exists, I get it, you can't have large company with shareholders and lots of employees update a complicated game in perpetuity for absolutely free, that's just not the real world as much as we wish it was. My issue is a combination of the volume, age, and price of the DLC working against the players. There is a lot of ancient DLC that adds features that other DLC later built off of, like Megacorp. I can't actually imagine playing without Megacorp, because in addition to adding mechanics the game feels absolutely naked without, it simultaneously adds value to other DLCs; e.x. Buy the necroids species and you get a unique civic for a corporate death cult. There's plenty of interactions like that and I would like the fact that old content kept adding value to new content... if Megacorp wasn't also still for sale separately too. And still $20- half the price of the entire base game. For an expansion that's 6 years old. It sucks too because now the newer DLC, instead of getting to build off the assumption of the older DLC , it ends up actually having ADDITIONAL pay-walled options instead of extra value. Instead of being a cute interaction, it's a double pay walled civic perk for $30 - you need BOTH to use it and it's not even a good one. It's really just unacceptable that 5+ year old DLC haven't been rolled into the base game, I refuse to believe whatever they'd lose on 'new' sales is more than what they're already losing by maintaining this impenetrable money wall that keeps out perspective players and pisses off older ones until they stop spending. 

Even if you want to argue that age doesn't depreciate the value of DLC (I disagree), then you still have to contend with the fact the volume of the DLC is a nightmare for anyone new or curious about the game - and that's not good for growing or even maintaining the player base. It's approaching an on-boarding cost that is simply unreasonable for anyone but true Dire Whales, and I do not believe Stellaris is the type of game to hold a Genshin tier whale pod that'll keep it afloat, it's just not that type of game. I started playing Stellaris shortly after it came out, I bought only the DLC I wanted as they came out and never felt salty about spending $10 or $20 once or sometimes twice a year to support a game I'm still enjoying. But anyone playing now has to purchase this entire back catalog - and if they want the same experience they need to buy years of DLC all at the same time instead of getting to space it out over years like I did to make the price tag easier to swallow. Sure, you don't NEED it, but that loops back around to, well, that's like half the features of the game. Maybe the review you read didn't mention that the one thing you wanted to try out is one of those DLC features - so now you have to do research before you buy it to make sure you're getting the experience you want. It's a mess of a purchasing decision that adds layers of complication it doesn't need as if TRYING to scare people away from spending money on it. It's truly baffling. If you have to choose between spending $300 on a full game or $30 on half a game, I feel like most are going to rightly choose "buy something else entirely". And I honestly think they're right to. 

(I will not address the subscription because I don't want to encourage it)

I waffled a lot on whether to ultimately give it a thumbs up or down because at the end of the day I do enjoy the game. I still put 8 hours into a new campaign every few months and I enjoy doing it. I prefer to review a game on it's own merits and what it is now, rather than what it could be or my feelings on any developer politics. But in the end it equally feels dishonest to anyone looking for genuine advice about it's worth if I said I recommended it. I think the only type of person this game is unarguably for is the kind of person who already knows it's for them and [b]very[/b] few others, especially in its current state.

it's, "okay." 6/10

customizing your starting faction means that your entire day of gaming is wasted on reaching the, "start," button and there's really no easy way to select one of the pregenerated options as a new player who doesn't understand their strengths and weaknesses

the game is well written with various random events, building and unit descriptions, and technologies but the strategy design is what I would describe as, "poor." within about 20-40 hours of playing you'll begin to see the flaws of the game and some design concepts make logically so little sense that you begin to question the game as a whole. An example of this is giving robot planets (which is a DLC purchase) access to all building slots without requiring them to build administration districts as you would with organic factions but then requiring them to build administration districts anyway for robot housing and amenities. looking deeper you'll see that population is king in this game and there is no, "build tall not wide option," and the reason for this is that it is more a visual novel than a strategy game.

I hesitated on Stellaris for a long time. I'd see promotions for it but couldn't wrap my head around what it is.  It wasn't until I tried Crusader Kings 3 that I realized Paradox's unique style and approaches to games.  (Which can be good and bad but more on that later.)  Stellaris is a strategy game in spirit of the Civilization series.  You basically take control of a stellar empire and try to build your way up in the galaxy,.  Much like the Civ series, there are multiple paths to a victory and even if you lose, you can still keep playing after someone is declared the victor.  Once you wrap your head around the formula, it's pretty fun. 

So the good? Stellaris is an excellent strategy game.  There are loads of technologies, civics, ethics and more in the game.  The models and graphics all look good for what it is.  The music is stellar (ha!) and keeps you in the mood while in a long marathon session.  I really enjoy the politics in the game and the depth of the technology trees. 

The bad: The most common complaint of any Paradox game is the DLC.  If you look at it from the standpoint of buying the game and waiting to buy the DLC somewhere down the line during a steam sale, it isn't so bad. But much like the Sims, jumping into the series after the release of like 15 DLCs is daunting and expensive. Luckily, they released the monthly subscription pack that while optional, gives you access to all the DLC.  I like it in ways because sometimes you may not be playing it as much so you can always cancel it.  

Overall: I am really enjoying the game. I had a few weeks off for Christmas break from work.  I got Indiana Jones on gamepass for PC. Played a little bit of it and ended up back on Stellaris for 3 days in a row instead. (not a knock, Indiana Jones is fun but I guess I ended up preferring to play Stellaris.) Here's hoping for many more hours. Oh, did I mention the mods? Paradox games are often mod friendly. You can find just about anything you want for this game! Even Star Wars and Star Trek total conversions!

Stellaris è semplicemente il mio gioco più giocato su steam, quindi da ciò si può comprendere quale sia il mio parere riguardo questo prodotto.
Semplicemente top, un capolavoro, un gioco sia strategico che geopolitico, che concerne la gestione di uno stato spaziale in ogni singolo aspetto di esso.
Ho giocato tanto alla modalità giocatore singolo, che personalmente trovo molto divertente in quanto l'IA è abbastanza avanzata e sa muoversi bene da sola, rendendo la sfida abbastanza complessa e costringendo il giocatore ad intraprendere la via della diplomazia, la quale quasi sempre è la miglior soluzione.
Nonostante ciò, ho giocato in egual misura alla modalità online in primis, e non appena è stata rilasciata anche alla modalità cooperativa, che trovo sia una spettacolare aggiunta, in grado di portare tanto divertimento per le persone che vogliono giocare utilizzando la stessa nazione galattica; nonostante ciò, ogni tanto quest'ultima modalità è affetta da diversi desync che iniziano ad avvenire una volta raggiunta la metà della partita.
In qualunque caso, la modalità online mi ha insegnato ancora di più le tattiche migliori da attuare in partita per superare la concorrenza degli altri stati, infatti giocare insieme ad uno o più amici può essere un grande vantaggio in questo prodotto, incoraggiando il lavoro di squadra e l'apprendimento imparando l'uno dall'altro le meccaniche di questo gioco che rimane uno dei giochi più complessi che io abbia mai giocato (in generale, la complessità è una caratteristica dei giochi di Paradox, come per Hearts of Iron IV e Crusader Kings III)
Gli sviluppatori rilasciano continui aggiornamenti e dlc, i quali purtroppo sono per la maggior parte a pagamento, ed il quale prezzo di un singolo dlc talvolta risulta esagerato, ma in qualunque caso la varietà delle meccaniche del gioco è in costante sviluppo, quindi troverete sempre nuove cose da fare per gestire il vostro stato al meglio.
Nonostante tutto, consiglio questo gioco in tutta la sua completezza.

184150560.review:
Stellaris is a grand strategy game set in the vastness of space, where players take control of an interstellar civilization. From exploring uncharted systems to engaging in diplomacy, warfare, and galactic empire-building, the game offers endless possibilities for creating and managing a unique spacefaring society. With its dynamic mechanics and rich storytelling, Stellaris provides an unparalleled sci-fi strategy experience.

[b]Key Features:[/b]

[b]Expansive Universe:[/b] Stellaris allows players to explore a procedurally generated galaxy filled with diverse star systems, planets, and mysterious anomalies. Each playthrough feels fresh and unique, with endless opportunities for discovery.

[b]Customizable Civilizations:[/b] Create your own civilization by choosing traits, ethics, government types, and species designs. This level of customization lets players shape their empire to reflect their strategic and narrative preferences.

[b]Dynamic Diplomacy:[/b] Engage in complex diplomatic interactions with other empires. Form alliances, negotiate trade agreements, or impose your will through intimidation. The game's dynamic AI ensures that diplomacy feels reactive and strategic.

[b]Deep Economic and Technological Systems:[/b] Manage resources such as minerals, energy, and alloys to build and maintain your empire. Research cutting-edge technologies to unlock powerful upgrades and new gameplay opportunities.

[b]Epic Space Battles:[/b] Command massive fleets in visually stunning space battles. The game's combat system emphasizes both strategic preparation and tactical execution, allowing players to design ships and outmaneuver opponents.

[b]Intriguing Storylines and Events:[/b] Stellaris features a wealth of narrative-driven events and quests, including ancient alien civilizations, galactic crises, and mysterious phenomena. These elements add depth and unpredictability to each campaign.

[b]Multiplayer Experience:[/b] Play with friends or compete against other players in multiplayer mode. The cooperative and competitive elements of multiplayer add a social dimension to the galaxy-spanning gameplay.

[b]Ongoing Updates and Expansions:[/b] Stellaris continues to evolve with regular updates and expansions that introduce new features, stories, and mechanics, ensuring long-term replayability and fresh content for players.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
Stellaris stands out as a masterpiece in the grand strategy genre, offering players the tools to shape their own interstellar saga. Its combination of deep mechanics, boundless customization, and captivating storytelling makes it a must-play for fans of sci-fi and strategy alike. Whether you’re a peaceful explorer or a ruthless conqueror, Stellaris offers a galaxy of possibilities for you to discover and dominate.

I really liked Stellaris. But I'm sorry.... every game that you cant buy as any kind of Complete Edition for $50€ at least a few years after release is pure scam. For $100€ you can buy dozens of games with much more variety of gameplay. Fresher ideas and more depth. This game is now almost 9years old.

Think about this:

The original game with all its game mechanics, visuals, sounds, engine, ideas from the concept stage to it being polished and ready for sale is $4€ now.  

Some of the DLC was ready when the original game shipped. Some was in different stages of development other ideas existed already.  Everything else that came after it is probably less complicated to do than the initial game yet costs 30x more. And some of it is based on community ideas too so not even their own intellectual creation.



Same reason why e.g. a SuperSmashBros on Switch for $50€ with 50 fighters and 50 stages that incluces the whole game enginge, graphics, sounds, menu, netcode etc....  is a steal compared to a single fighter with a stage that costs $5€.    

There is no way DLC is worth what people demand for it. And at that point every developer loses (and should lose) every customer that has at least a minimum amount of self respect.

If this game will ever be "PAY $50€ and you will get everything that exists and will ever exist." Then I will buy it.  Making games is easier than it ever was especially with A.I now.

I am writing this because I would like to play the content yes. I already said I liked the original game. But there is no way I could ever justify spending the overpriced price for the DLC. I much rather spend my money where I get more value for it.

184042624.review:
This is a Civilization game in space. It has a lot of detail, a lot of nuance, and is extremely complicated. For RTS lovers, this is great. But drawback number 1: There is no tutorial, no explanation, and no way to know how to play the game without just getting in an loosing a few times.

There's a bit of an explanation such as "This window is where you manage your colony," which, OK, the window says Colony Management, so thanks. But what does this icon mean? What does this modifier mean? What does this building do? I guess I'll go sift through the wiki for an hour... 

Drawback number 2: the game is fundamentally unbalanced. If you try to do anything other than build up your army then you are going to loose. I have played a dozen games that all ended the same way: I'm 7 hours in, making my way to the top of the science or diplomacy or trade victories, and then some random wandering fleet stumbles into my empire and lays waste to everything.

I decided to uninstall after a 12-hour game ended with a random pirate faction (automatically hostile, immune to diplomacy) entered my empire, made a straight-line shot for my home world, blew up every ship I had, and then destroyed my colonies. Oh, and the pirates were so strong I couldn't destroy even a single ship.

What is the point of all the complex civilization and empire management systems if the game is always decided by the guy with the biggest guns? Why spend time building up trade routes or alliances or espionage if the pirates could show up at any minute and just wipe me off the map?

If they can figure out a balance for this, I might return to the game. For now, I do not recommend the purchase.

What they did not foresee, was that with the left over resources and just being 10x smarter butterflies just nuked their ships to splinters (while human tech was equivalent of space axes and sticks). But! How would the measly butterflies take back the planet, when the armies are killed with a gust of wind? Never fear! Let's invent some robots for just this purpose.

184038911.review:
[b]Stellaris[/b] ist zweifelsohne eines der besten Strategiespiele, die ich je gespielt habe. Von der ersten Sekunde an wird man in eine faszinierende und unendliche Galaxie katapultiert, in der jede Entscheidung, die man trifft, weitreichende Konsequenzen hat. Das Hauptspiel bietet bereits eine beeindruckende Grundlage an Möglichkeiten, unterschiedlichen Rassen und komplexen Mechaniken, die die Neugier und den Entdeckerdrang wecken. Doch die wahre Pracht entfaltet sich erst mit den zahlreichen DLCs, die bis 2024 erschienen sind.

Die Vielfalt der Reiche und Spezies, die man erstellen kann, ist einfach überwältigend. Jede Entscheidung, ob es sich um die Auswahl einer Spezies, die Wahl des Regierungssystems oder die strategische Ausrichtung der Forschung handelt, führt zu einem einzigartigen Spielerlebnis. Die verschiedenen DLCs, wie "Distant Stars", "Federations", "Nemesis" und "Overlord", erweitern das Gameplay auf bemerkenswerte Weise. Besonders "Federations" bringt eine neue Dimension der Diplomatie und des politischen Spiels ins Geschehen, während "Distant Stars" mit aufregenden Erzählsträngen und Geheimnissen punktet, die das Erkunden der Galaxie noch spannender machen.

Die Musik ist ein weiteres Highlight von Stellaris. Der mitreißende Soundtrack untermalt die Epik des Spiels und sorgt dafür, dass man sich tief in die Atmosphäre der intergalaktischen Abenteuer hineinziehen lässt. Die Kombination aus futuristischen Klängen und majestätischen Melodien schafft eine immersive Erfahrung, die das Spiel noch unvergesslicher macht.

Ein weiterer Pluspunkt ist der hohe Wiederspielwert. Jedes Spiel gestaltet sich anders, sei es durch die Wahl einer neuen Spezies, das Ausloten anderer Strategien oder das Eingehen auf verschiedene Ereignisse und Geschichten, die sich während der Erkundung entfalten. Man findet sich oft in neuen, unerwarteten Situationen wieder, die einen dazu anregen, immer wieder neue Ansätze auszuprobieren.

Allerdings ist zu beachten, dass Stellaris eine gewisse Komplexität mit sich bringt. Die Vielzahl an Mechaniken und Strategien erfordert, dass man sich intensiv mit dem Spiel auseinandersetzt, um das volle Potenzial auszuschöpfen. Doch genau diese Herausforderung macht das Spiel so lohnenswert. Wenn man erst einmal den Dreh raus hat, wird man belohnt mit einem tiefgründigen und fesselnden Erlebnis.

Insgesamt ist Stellaris ein herausragendes Spiel, das durch seine Vielfalt, das durchdachte Design der Reiche und die packenden Geschichten besticht. Mit den DLCs wird das Gameplay kontinuierlich erweitert und bereichert. Wer bereit ist, sich in die komplexe, aber faszinierende Welt von Stellaris zu vertiefen, wird mit unzähligen Stunden voller Freude und Entdeckungen belohnt. Ein absolutes Muss für jeden Strategiefan!
