183979522.review:
A great and fun game locked behind unintuitive UI choices and unexplained gameplay mechanics that get really annoying very fast.

Every Empire is Japan 1945 and will never surrender, even if you occupy every planet in their system, which leads to that you have to claim every system of theirs and then settle for peace. After which you have to wait a time until a truce agreement ended. I have an overwhelming army compared to theirs, why would hold myself to an truce agreement?

War exhaustiong is an unexplained weird mechanic that builds up overtime, so both parties dont go into stalemates. Why my war exhausting goes up so fast even when i win every battle i do not know. How would i? it was never explained proper in the first place. 

Empires can just close their borders on you, which makes it impossible to travers their land. Not that you can choose to respect their choices or not, no. Closed borders make it magically impossible for your warships to traverse like some magic field was installed. Got your ships trapped in another empire your with war with? now you gotta declare war on the other nation so your ships can leave.

There are so many different recourses in the game that often only do one or two things and so complicate things with no reason. You load up your first game and instantly feel like you have been hit by a semitruck of information. Since this games version of a tutorial is a text field with short information of the thing you just pressed, the number one thing searched on youtube is "stellaris tutorial"

i like this game and i will play it some more, but it really makes it hard to say it my fav game.

183928404.review: Jogo de estratégia muito bom, com elementos de gerenciamento de economia, frota e base. O jogo possibilita a formação de federação, seja com fins de pesquisa ou guerra. Sistema de vassalagem e dominio de território. Sua civilização começa com as configurações de espécie e traços de governo estipulados pelo jogador, antes do início da partida, permitindo um foco maior na criação de naves com desconto, ou exploração de itens. IA bem agressiva, que tende sempre a tentar cercar o jogador e impedir a expansão, "estrangulando" o seu progresso pelo mapa estelar nos sistemas interconectados. Há algumas diferenças por espécie e planeta, que fazem a análise do terreno e buffs de construção uma opção sensata antes de uma aquisição de território. A IA age rápido e de forma implacável, fazendo com que se necessite pausar algumas vezes, ou diminuir o fluxo de passagem do tempo para uma boa olhada no império do jogador, a fim de impedir déficit de recursos ou possíveis revoltas das colonias desamparadas. Todas as naves podem ser customizadas com seus tipos de armas, conforme o desbloqueio da pesquisa. Os líderes funcionam como heróis da civilização, propiciando bonus de acordo com a escolha do jogador. Jogo divertido de jogar com amigos pacientes, que queiram aprender a gerenciar a partida e que saibam seguir dicas dos jogadores mais experientes. Qualquer um que tenha jogado e não recomenda esse jogo, possivelmente se frustrou pela expectativa de um Age of Empires ou jogos simples de estratégia de guerra, quando na verdade este jogo cresceu muito mais com as DLCs constantes, que rechearam o jogo de possibilidades e o tornou um jogo muito mais complexo do que simplesmente coletar madeira e carne e criar um soldado que bate no inimigo. A perda de naves e necessidade de reparo e escolha de um comandante de frota, remete aos antigos jogos de Star Trek Armada. Vale a pena jogar. O jogo base é caro, assim como as DLCs, então sugiro aguardar uma promoção que vá até 70 reais aproximadamente, lembrando que somente um jogador (Host da partida) precisa ter todas as DLCs, para que os demais players possam jogar o conteúdo completo. Tenho 697 horas jogadas no momento desta análise e só consegui completar a coleção depois de anos de jogo. Vale a pena aproveitar as promoções, que nesse momento estão com 90% no jogo base(R$14,39) e 50% nas DLCs. Recomendo esforço e paciência para aprender a jogar.

183909120.review:
The absolute pinnacle of 4X and strategy game in my eyes. No game has come close in engaging my imagination, focus, and creativity. I love the feeling of creating my own space opera (dune, star wars, etc), learning the interwoven systems that make the simulation feel so believable, and pondering my next move as I go about my day. If you at all loved imagining what the rest of the Star Wars, Dune, or Star Trek universes were doing as the main story went on, you'll find so much joy and excitement in Stellaris. Words fail me! I love this game!

The continuous bug fixes, reworks of old broken systems, and mostly great DLC makes me feel so relieved and happy that Stellaris will have a long life and will go down in history as the gold standard for the genre. I own all the DLC and have definitely gotten my money's worth, especially since they continuously update and fix older content!

There is no genre of video games as rewarding as the grand strategy / simulation ones. If you are at all intimidated by Stellaris but still curious - the game can be played as slowly as you'd like, and is meant to be enjoyed over the course of days and weeks, rather than crammed into a late weekend night. Just launch the game and start as the humans, and just let yourself play it for a short while each day as the week goes on. Your brain will retain and learn new things each night. Stellaris, along with Crusader Kings 3, are the most beginner friendly of the paradox / grand strategy games out there!

183830851.review:
根据搜索结果，以下是对《群星》（Stellaris）这款游戏的综合评价：

1. **游戏特色与自由度**：
   - 《群星》是一款以探索型太空幻想策略沙盒游戏，允许玩家在星海中发现奇迹，从初入星海到将整个星系尽收囊中，玩家可以自由地发现并讲述自己独特的故事。
   - 游戏提供了极高的自由度，玩家可以自行设计帝国的政府机构，甚至自由定义物种，从而提供新鲜的游戏体验。
   - 游戏依托于预设的故事情节以及随机生成的机制和叙事模块，构筑出意料之外、自然生成的叙事，给玩家带来对未知的期待与奇迹的发现。

2. **游戏机制与玩法**：
   - 作为4X游戏（探索、扩张、开发、消灭），《群星》的核心机制是4X=探索地图→扩张领土→发展经济→干爆敌人，技巧成分较低，更多依赖策略。
   - 游戏深受玩家喜爱的关键在于其丰富的模拟系统能和太空探索与星际战争这个主题产生相当棒的化学反应。
   - 玩家可以在宏观战略视角模拟体验银河系文明的全局发展与演化，游戏包含了未来世界中的资源、人口、治安、政体、意识形态等元素。

3. **游戏更新与DLC**：
   - 《群星》是一个有生命的游戏，随着时间的推移，游戏已经发展壮大，以满足玩家群体的愿望，添加了更深入的角色扮演元素。
   - 游戏的DLC和mod为游戏增加了更多的故事性和可玩性，尤其是对于喜欢贸易和外交的玩家来说，这些元素让游戏更加丰富。

4. **玩家反馈与体验**：
   - 玩家普遍认为《群星》是一款非常优秀的轻度策略游戏，随机性给予了它无尽的开放性。
   - 有玩家表示，游戏玩起来挺上头的，和《文明6》的“再来一回合”差不多，能够让人沉浸其中。
   - 也有玩家提到，游戏有时会有BUG，比如格式塔日常的节点下班问题，但整体上，如果玩家喜欢这类游戏，那么《群星》是一个不错的选择。

5. **专业评测**：
   - IGN给出的评分是7.4分，认为《群星》主机版的体验超前，但版本滞后，因为移植的版本不是最新的，而是旧版，这使得一些老玩家感到不满。

综上所述，《群星》是一款深受策略游戏爱好者喜爱的太空4X大战略游戏，以其丰富的模拟系统、高自由度和不断更新的DLC而受到玩家的好评。游戏提供了一个宏观的战略视角，让玩家体验银河系文明的发展与演化，同时也存在一些需要改进的地方，如BUG和旧版本的移植问题。
——来自小黑盒用户木几乂的评价

83% of Stellaris owners never conquered another nations planet according to the steam achievements.
94.1% of Stellaris owners never have finished and won a singleplayer campaign

Even the starter edition is $50, now at an all time low because of the winter sales at $18. Yet for this price they only give you 2 DLC's (Utopia and Synthetic Dawn). 2 great expansions but still only a incredibly small addition to what this game has to offer at such a steep price.

Not a singular new player stumbling upon Stellaris is willing to put down $150 for a bunch of DLC's, instead they'll buy the cheaper versions without any or very little DLC's. And be quickly disappointed (in most cases) as these versions only hold 5/100th of what the game has to offer. And if they do enjoy it, they'll have to spend a bunch of money on additional DLC's just to prolong their enjoyment of the game

I really feel like this is a huge reason why most of the influx of new players during sales instantly vanishes the next month, and why the multiplayer scene is rotten and dying.

First, the game is great. One of the best 4x games ever made.

So why do I not recommend it? Mostly because of Paradox's development strategy of constantly releasing more and more content - stuffing the game like Homer being served donuts in hell - has created a unique feeling of ennui. Stellaris and Crusader Kings have proven that there indeed can be too much of a good thing.

I shouldn't feel exhausted at the idea of playing the game, but I do. The knowledge of all the DLC and expansions, some I have some I don't, some I need some are optional. It's just... exhausting. The subscription service they offer to unlock all DLC for a monthly fee is a solution sure, but I don't like it. It is gross to me and feels like the type of thing you'd see in a cash vampire mobile game. but Paradox games nowadays are cash vampires... so I guess they're a match made in heaven.

Tl;dr Great game, I hate it.

My favorite game, but be prepared for the price tag of eight years (at time of review) of DLC from a DLC heavy studio. However, it's all great DLC that expands the game experience. They've introduced a monthly fee as an alternative to buying all the DLC, which I'd recommend trying if you want to get a feel for the game. Or just play with someone who has the DLC: game hosts allow the DLC for all other players. 

With that said, it's the best sci-fi civilization building game out there, with plenty of variety in it's random events and the scenarios from your starting civilization to galaxy settings ensure you'll keep having a great experience. The game also receives regular updates to the base game with a team focused on improving core mechanics with two teams (as of now) working on DLC for the game to expand on it.

It has a plethora of difficulty adjustments and customization, and I'm sure I'll get a couple of thousand more hours out of it.

I’ve been a long-time player of this game, and I genuinely enjoy it. However, I’m increasingly disappointed by the design choices in recent updates. The new content often feels disconnected from the old, with little effort to ensure balance or cohesion. It seems like a collection of separate projects rather than parts of a unified vision.

It’s as if the teams working on different DLCs never collaborate or communicate, which results in a fragmented experience. The game could greatly benefit from a period of consolidation—bringing all the elements together, balancing them, and creating a clear, coherent direction for future development. I believe this approach would enhance the player experience and allow the game to truly shine.

183706547.review: Early game this game is awesome and fun. Once i got to mid game the performance started dropping during wars. Now i'm in late game with large wars going on and the game is a slide show with the lowest graphic settings I could apply. I've tried mutiple things people have suggested but nothing helped. I am running a 14700k, 64gb ram, and a 4070. once war started the game becomes unplayable and randomly crashes when I tried to suffer through it. I did more research on this and found this. Stellaris's Core Issue: The game relies heavily on single-threaded processes, meaning many of its core calculations are performed by a single CPU core. This creates a bottleneck, even on powerful multi-core CPUs. Sadly paradox is aware of this and has not fixed it yet. wish I would have looked into this before I purchased the game.

183665949.review: "Stellaris" is an outstanding game that offers a captivating and immersive experience. The depth of its strategic gameplay is remarkable, allowing players to manage every aspect of their interstellar empire, from colonizing planets to diplomatic negotiations with other species. The vast array of customization options for species, ships, and technologies provides endless replayability. The graphics are visually stunning, bringing the galaxy to life with beautiful celestial bodies and detailed ship designs. The game's expansions have continuously enhanced the gameplay, introducing new mechanics and storylines. However, the learning curve can be a bit steep for newcomers, and the mid to late-game performance might sometimes lag. Despite these minor drawbacks, "Stellaris" remains a top-tier strategy game that will keep you hooked for countless hours as you strive to build and expand your galactic dominion.

183591852.review:
It's a Paradox Interactive game, and that means that you need to watch ten hours of videos to even be able to do anything, the UX is horrible and it's going to take another hour to figure out how to do something you MUST do, and the help files won't tell you, they'll obliquely gesture to it. Set the THING in PANEL. And then you spend ten minutes clicking random things and doing yet more web searches until you find it. 

And yet you'll play it for tens of hours.

It's pretty meh. Without an historical setting to frame the game, the glaring artificiality of it is apparent and how it's really just a box full of game mechanics, without anything like a story to hold it together. Sure, sure, there's some oblique references to Stanislaw Lem here, but it's not like it's based on the works of Lem. It's a grab bag of tropes. The DLC are more tropes thrown together. If they're tropes you like, it's fun. But as more and more of them are available, it's a stone soup of a game. A generic stew that doesn't taste bad, but it's not got anything to make it taste good.

And yet you'll play it for tens of hours.

If you like Paradox Interactive games, it's not as fun, nor as innovative as CK3, but not as drab as others. It's both compelling and boring. You'll like it as a palate cleanser and go back to others after you have played it for tens or hundreds of hours.

183545663.review:
Good game, great game even. The mechanics are pretty easy to get a hold on for a new player, I had no problem figuring out what everything did and the best way to do x to get y. The lore feels rewarding to try to find and there are so many little tidbits and story snacks to consume sometimes I forget that each galaxy is random.  Sometimes the game can get pretty slow, only to hit you with 55 notifications, six different attacking fleets, and a mid-game crisis. Things can get overwhelming sometimes, and in my opinion, that's when the game truly shines. Feeling like your empire is one starbase away from destruction, yet somehow keeping it together is an unmatched feeling that I just haven't gotten from other games until now.
You get to create your own empire (duh), but when you do there is a chance for that empire to show up as an NPC in one of your games which was SO COOL when I first saw it. It sounds lame, but trust me, it's a nice refresher to have a personalized and life- like empire instead of the boring regular ones. (don't get me wrong, there is nothing wrong with the base ones, It's just less fun as they lack creativity compared to fighting the imperium of man for example). The play styles are amazing to try out, I personally love eradicating empires as life-hating communist robots from space Moscow. This game lets you take so many paths of action, I love it. It isn't unheard of, but it's another great boon.
The game isn't without its faults, the roll system is infuriating in the early game when you can't spare leaders for example, but they are minor and so few it makes the game feel polished to perfection, at least for me personally.  Definitely one of my faves.

183522491.review:
Look at the time I’ve put into Stellaris. I promise you, none of that time is idle. This game… well, it isn’t my absolute favorite, although my playtime might suggest otherwise. But it is my go-to “mindless” game—the one I turn to when nothing else feels enjoyable. And the thing is, Stellaris is far from mindless! I’ve just played it so much that I’ve seen and done it all.

Still, this game is always enjoyable. It’s a 10/10 experience and, in my opinion, the best 4X space strategy game out there. If you’re on the fence about diving into the vastness of the galaxy, don’t hesitate. There’s so much depth, variety, and replayability here—it’s worth every minute.
